Glycemic Index Of Wheat Roti

The glycemic index of wheat roti is relatively high as compared to other grains. This is due to the higher amount of carbohydrate present in wheat roti as compared to other grains. A high glycemic index indicates that the carbohydrates present in wheat roti are quickly broken down and absorbed in the body, leading to a sudden increase in the blood sugar levels. High glycemic index foods like wheat roti should be consumed in moderation to maintain the desired health. It is advised to combine wheat roti with proteins and good fats to slow down the digestion process and lower its glycemic index. Additionally, consuming wheat roti with more fiber-rich ingredients like pulses or vegetables can also help reduce its glycemic index.

When it comes to glycemic index value, wheat roti is not the healthiest food option. Generally, the glycemic index of roti is around 70 which means it is a high glycemic index food. On the other hand, some healthier food options like oats, brown rice, fruits and vegetables have a glycemic index of around 55-65, making them the ideal choice for those looking for healthier food options. Moreover, foods with a low glycemic index helps in managing blood sugar levels and are also great for weight management. Therefore, it is recommended to choose healthier food options over wheat roti to maintain good health.

Here are the top 10 wheat roti alternatives for diabetics: 1) Whole wheat tortilla; 2) Spelt bread; 3) Millet chapati; 4) Buckwheat chapati; 5) Sorghum chapati; 6) Quinoa chapati; 7) Brown rice chapati; 8) Oats chapati; 9) Amaranth chapati; 10) Barley chapati. All these ingredients are low on the glycemic index and provide all the nutrition of wheat roti. Diabetics can enjoy a variety of rotis with these healthy alternatives.
